title: Australians brief victims’ families on decision to take in men U.S. once accused of tourist massacre
text:
Family members who attended the audiences with Australian High Commissioner Patricia Forsythe said they appreciated the gesture but left dissatisfied with the Australians’ unwillingness to provide detailed answers to questions about the unusual decision to take in so-called refugees held in the U.S. for nearly a decade and a half after a criminal prosecution of the two men and a third Rwandan went awry.

“To sum it all up, it was incredibly disappointing — heartwrenching, really,” Melissa Jackson, Avis’ sister, said of her family’s meeting with officials at the Australian consulate in Auckland. “There was no compassion, no nothing…It was purely business and a business meeting.”

Michelle’s parents, Peter and Jean, and older sister Joanna met Forsythe — who’s effectively the Australian ambassador to New Zealand — at a Christchurch hotel. Peter Strathern detected a bit more understanding, saying that an immigration aide who attended that session with Forsythe was “almost in tears” at one point.

“They said they were very sorry about what had happened to Michelle,” Peter Strathern said. He asked why no effort was made to get input from the families or even to notify them before or after the men were resettled in Australia. “Privacy” was the mantra Forsythe and her aide offered in return.

“They don’t normally do that, they said. They said, because of privacy reasons, they don’t do that,” Strathern said. “There were certain things they could not tell us.”

The two Rwandans — Leonidas Bimenyimana and Gregoire Nyaminani — were charged with first-degree murder over the massacre and faced the possibility of the death penalty in a U.S. court until a judge threw out their confessions in 2006, citing evidence the men, former Hutu fighters, were tortured while in Rwandan government custody. The men then fought their deportation from the U.S. to Rwanda, arguing that they could be persecuted or killed if returned to the Tutsi-led government there.

POLITICO reported earlier this year that the stalemate over the Rwandans was broken after they became part of discussions that led to a broader, immigration-related deal between the U.S. and Australia. In that pact, the U.S. agreed to help solve a much-larger scale immigration problem for Australia by accepting as many as 1,250 migrants intercepted at sea and held for years in offshore detention centers that became a political albatross for multiple Australian governments.

Due to persistent secrecy on the part of both the U.S. and Australian governments, precisely how the Rwandan men fit into that deal remains unclear, but last November the two were released from an immigration detention center in Virginia and flown to Australia.

The transfer came nearly two years after then-Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull told President Donald Trump that Australia had agreed to take in people the Obama administration was “very keen on getting out of the United States,” according to a transcript leaked to the Washington Post. Trump initially balked at keeping Obama’s pledge to take in the migrants Australia was seeking to offload, but was eventually persuaded to stand by the deal.

One mystery the victims’ families have sought to unravel is how the Rwandan men passed a so-called “character test” that is supposed to be part of Australia’s screening process for refugees and asylum applicants.

Although the men denied involvement in the massacre and the dismissal of the murder charges meant they were never convicted of any crime, the victims' families questioned how the pair were deemed of good character since they admitted to fighting on behalf of the Army for the Liberation of Rwanda, or ALIR — a Hutu militia linked to numerous atrocities, which is still formally listed as a terrorist group by the U.S.

Both families said Forsythe insisted that a full character investigation on the two men was conducted and they passed, although she would not provide details.

“I don’t think they actually passed the test,” Jackson said. “I think somebody’s done a dodgy back-pocket, back handed deal to get these guys out of the States. I think it’s disgusting.”

Both families said Australian officials offered up a previously unheard explanation for taking in the former Rwandan fighters: a heightened obligation on Australia’s part to address refugee cases involving Rwanda because that nation, like Australia, is part of the Commonwealth. (Rwanda joined the group formerly known as the British Commonwealth in 2009, despite having no colonial ties to the United Kingdom.)

“The lady mentioned that Rwanda is part of the Commonwealth,” said Pauline Jackson, Avis’ mother. “Turns out Commonwealth countries take people from Rwanda on humanitarian grounds if they’re part of families who were in the genocide. I think it’s our back door for, kind of, criminals.”

Asked about the meetings with the families, a spokesperson for Australia’s Home Affairs Department offered only a generic statement.

“Australia works with our closest partners — the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, and New Zealand, as an active participant in addressing global migration challenges,” the spokesperson said. “The Department of Home Affairs observes privacy requirements and does not disclose the details of its conversations.”

Australian officials did not respond directly to questions about their discussions with New Zealand on the resettlement, nor about how Rwanda’s commonwealth status impacted the decision to admit the two men.

Queries from Rhonda Avis’ family to the New Zealand government did yield one new bit of information. While Australia doesn’t appear to have told their long-time Kiwi allies in advance about the deal, officials did notify their New Zealand counterparts before POLITICO broke news of the transfers.

New Zealand Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters told Jackson in a letter last month that New Zealand officials “were informed about this matter in March 2019, after resettlement had occurred.”

“New Zealand did not play a role in Australia’s decision in this case. However, we are confident that Australia has a robust screening process for refugees,” Peters wrote.

While not addressing any specifics, he assured Jackson that anyone associated with groups involved in war crimes could be denied visas if deemed “a risk to New Zealand’s international reputation.”

Meanwhile, Peter Strathern said his family is still struggling to come to terms with Australia’s decision, despite disagreeing with it and feeling that many of their questions remain unanswered.

“We told them how we felt,” he said. “We weren’t particularly happy with the outcome. But we’ve been down this track and so, we’ve sort of accepted that that’s what it is.”
